hints.content: Start by identifying the smallest and largest numbers in the array. You can use built-in functions like `min()` and `max()` in Python to achieve this easily.
Remember that the greatest common divisor (GCD) is the largest number that divides both numbers without leaving a remainder. Think about how you can calculate the GCD of two numbers.
To find the GCD, you can use the Euclidean algorithm. This algorithm is efficient and works by repeatedly replacing the larger number by its remainder when divided by the smaller number.
Consider edge cases where the smallest and largest numbers are the same. What would the GCD be in that scenario? Think about how your code should handle this situation.
Make sure to handle the input constraints. The array will always have at least two elements, and each element will be between 1 and 1000. This can help you optimize your solution.
After finding the smallest and largest numbers, store them in variables for clarity. This will make your GCD calculation easier to read and maintain.
You can implement the GCD function either iteratively or recursively. Choose the method you are more comfortable with, but ensure it handles all cases correctly.
When implementing the GCD function, consider using a while loop for the iterative approach. It will continue until one of the numbers becomes zero.
Once you have the GCD, remember to return it as your final output. Ensure your function adheres to the expected return format.
Finally, test your solution with various edge cases, including arrays with duplicate values and arrays where the smallest and largest numbers are the same.

questionNotes: Return the GCD of the smallest and largest numbers in the array.
